Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Expectation2: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation2: Your I04iend calls, sounding very upset, and asks if you have a moment to talk about a recent argument with their partner.
Story: It was Saturday afternoon, and I had just sent my mom a quick text: “Hey, just checking in! Hope you and Dad are well.” I knew she liked hearing from me on weekends, and I tried to keep up the habit, even if it was just a short message. As I set my phone down, it buzzed again—this time, it was my friend, Sarah. Her name flashed on the screen, and when I answered, her voice was shaky. “Can you talk? I really need someone right now,” she said, barely holding back tears. I could hear the pain in her words, and I knew she expected me to listen, to be there for her like I always promised. But just as I was about to respond, my mom replied, asking if I could call her for a quick chat. She missed me, and I hadn’t spoken to her all week. My heart twisted as I stared at my phone, torn between being the daughter my mom hoped for and the friend Sarah needed.
